author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Elvia Ramirez Dies at 17; Youngest Covid-19 Victim in North Dakota
description: Her mother watched her heartbreaking decline over three swift weeks, starting in mid-September, when Elvia began experiencing headaches.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: The Capital of Sprawl Gets a Radically Car-Free Neighborhood
description: On an empty lot near Phoenix, perhaps the most auto-addicted city in America, a start-up is betting $170 million on a more walkable future.
content: Phoenix, that featureless and ever-spreading tundra of concrete, has been called “the world’s least sustainable city.” It has been characterized as a “sprawling, suburbanite wasteland” and “a monument to man’s arrogance.” The Onion has darkly predicted that by 2050, “most of Earth’s landmass” will be swallowed by the encroaching Phoenix exurbs. The Walk Score index ranks the place as the second-worst big city in America for pedestrians, and traversing it has been described as “a slog through a desert, plus the occasional McDonald’s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian Provinces Hit by a Second Wave of Coronavirus
description: Overall, Russia’s health care system is coping with a fall surge in cases, but bodies are piling up in overwhelmed regional hospitals and morgues.
content: MOSCOW — One video shows bodies in plastic bags stacked in the basement of a hospital in the Siberian city of Barnaul after a morgue overflowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: With early voting underway in Florida, Democrats worry about Black and Latino support.
description: With turnout the key to victory in Florida, some Democrats have expressed concern about a lack of enthusiasm from Black and Latino voters.
content: As the sun set on the C. Blythe Andrews Jr. Public Library in Tampa on Friday evening, a steady stream of mostly Black voters trickled in, hoping to cast their ballots four days before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Police Reform Is on the Ballot
description: When it comes to curbing violence by law enforcement, local elections matter most.
content: In 2017, after the Portland, Ore., police fatally shot her 17-year-old grandson, Donna Hayes got invited to City Hall to meet Mayor Ted Wheeler, who expressed his deepest sympathies. He had been in office for only seven weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Thomas Kaplan and Michael D. Shear
title: Final Weekend Campaigning Reflects Both Traditional Barnstorming and 2020 Chaos
description: The candidates visited two of the key “Blue Wall” states Mr. Trump won in 2016.
content: President Trump predicted “bedlam” and a lack of clarity about the presidential results until weeks after Election Day as he barnstormed Pennsylvania, while former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. made his first joint appearance with former President Barack Obama at an event in Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: James Bond Actors Say Sean Connery ‘Defined an Era and a Style’
description: Other actors who have portrayed Agent 007 remembered Mr. Connery, who died at 90, for his charm, screen presence and golfing.
content: Sean Connery was remembered on Saturday by other James Bond actors and franchise producers as “one of the true greats of cinema” who most embodied the fictional spy character James Bond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Patricia Mazzei
title: Obama will head to South Florida and Atlanta on Monday, Biden campaign announces.
description: Obama will head to South Florida and Atlanta on Monday, Biden campaign announces.
content: Former President Barack Obama will travel to to Atlanta and South Florida on Monday, the Biden campaign announced Saturday afternoon, a move aimed at boosting turnout in closely contested states where victories for the former vice president would open multiple paths to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: I’m Dreaming of a Blue Texas
description: With every election cycle, the same question comes up: Is this the year the Lone Star State changes its color?
content: It’s happening again — the belief that this is the year Texas will turn blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: West-Southwest
description: Julian Lim’s Sunday puzzle tilts us slightly in another direction.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Weekend solvers are familiar with Julian Lim; he’s constructed 11 themeless Fridays and Saturdays for the Times over the last several years. This might strike you as logical, if you’re noticing (like I did) a high degree of difficulty in the fill. This is only Mr. Lim’s second Sunday; its theme is straightforward and low-key brilliant, in my opinion, when viewed as a whole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The President’s Taxes: A Reader’s Guide
description: Over the past four years, The New York Times has independently obtained and published information on several decades of Donald J. Trump’s taxes.
content: Over the last several weeks, The New York Times has published the findings of its investigation into more than 20 years of President Trump’s federal income tax records — information that he has fought to keep hidden in defiance of presidential tradition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: He’s a Rare House Republican in a District Trump Lost. Can He Hold On?
description: Representative John Katko has managed to keep his seat in Central New York by distancing himself from the president. Will that be enough this year?
content: Two years ago, a pair of House Republicans in Central New York became prime targets for the Democratic Party, which had hoped to unseat them in the midterm elections by exploiting voters’ unhappiness with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: ‘They’re Calling You on the Squid Phone’
description: Cephalopod researchers were surprised by the sighting of a ram’s horn squid, a peculiar animal never before filmed in its natural environment.
content: Earlier this week, and more than 2,700 feet underwater by the northern Great Barrier Reef, a remotely operated vehicle named SuBastian engaged in a stare-off with a burrito. That’s what the creature looked like from a distance: an untoasted cylinder floating eerily upright in the ocean’s twilight zone, like takeout from Triton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Sturtz
title: What if They Could Make the Pandemic Go Poof?
description: The crisis facing magicians is unprecedented. “It’s a scary, scary time,” said one.
content: It was a Sunday evening, and Ken Scott’s audience was spellbound. Parents and children were oohing and ahhing as he delivered a string of miracles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Fueled by Cash, Health Care and Trump’s Woes, Democrats Aim for Senate Control
description: Republicans are battling to hold off losses by warning of the risks of unified Democratic power in Washington, but they concede their majority is in peril.
content: BOZEMAN, Mont. — Voters caught up in this state’s exceedingly close Senate race could be forgiven for believing Gov. Steve Bullock, the Democratic candidate, was sharing the ballot with Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Terrapin Topper
description: Stella Zawistowski brings us a Saturday puzzle with bite.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This sharp Stella Zawistowski grid is like an Australian “mystery flight,” full of misdirects and international flair. There are loads of odd interesting entries, none faddish, many charmingly retro (like these guys, from 1994). Also, note how lovingly Ms. Zawistowski clues her little fill, all those short entries that we need to solve in order to chip away at the tough stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: After Trump accuses doctors of profiteering, medical professionals push back.
description: At a rally in Michigan on Friday, President Trump repeated an extraordinary and unfounded claim that American doctors were profiteering from coronavirus deaths.
content: At a rally in Michigan on Friday, President Trump repeated an extraordinary and unfounded claim that American doctors were profiteering from coronavirus deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: The Yarn Store Would Like You to Vote
description: And so would nearly every company out there this year.
content: A few nights ago, Shana Gadarian, a political scientist at Syracuse University, was ordering a takeout dinner when the DoorDash app suggested she use the time waiting for her order to “make a voting plan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Police in North Carolina use a chemical spray to disperse a get-out-the-vote rally.
description: Police officers and sheriff’s deputies in Graham, N.C., deployed a chemical spray and arrested eight people at a get-out-the-vote march and rally on Saturday, according to the police and participants.
content: Police officers and sheriff’s deputies in Graham, N.C., deployed a chemical spray and arrested eight people at a march and rally on Saturday that were intended to honor George Floyd and encourage people to vote, according to the police and participants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Jim Rutenberg and Maggie Haberman
title: Their First Try Backfired, but Giuliani and Allies Keep Aiming at Biden
description: The former New York mayor’s dirt-digging effort on Hunter Biden in 2019 ended with President Trump’s impeachment. Now he is back with new associates. So far it is not going exactly as planned.
content: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Greek Orthodox Priest Wounded in Lyon, France, Shooting
description: An unknown assailant fired twice at the priest before fleeing the scene, authorities said. The attack came amid heightened tensions in France after an Islamist terrorist attack in Nice that left three dead.
content: PARIS — A Greek Orthodox priest was shot and wounded Saturday in the central French city of Lyon, but the motive was unclear, local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Poll Watchers Endure, Minus the Partisan Drama
description: As President Trump urges supporters to watch for fraud at polling places, people inside the polls already are keeping watch — and usually not finding much.
content: WASHINGTON — Amid the clamor of President Trump’s continuing demands for his supporters to look out for fraud at polling places, it is easy to overlook the fact that in many polling places, someone already is keeping watch.
source.name: The New York Times

title: N.E.H. Funds Restoration of Statues Toppled During Protests
description: Statues of Christopher Columbus in Baltimore and a Union Army colonel in Madison, Wis., will be repaired.
content: In response to an executive order from President Trump condemning the destruction of historical monuments during recent racial justice protests, the National Endowment for the Humanities is allocating $90,000 to repair or rebuild damaged statues, including one of Christopher Columbus that was toppled in Baltimore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: As Augmented Reality Evolves, the Reporting Is All Around You
description: A new storytelling initiative is rooted in the belief that information is “not going to be on a sliver of glass forever.”
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent Geisser
title: Is France Fueling Muslim Terrorism by Trying to Prevent It?
description: Emmanuel Macron’s government may unwittingly be breeding the kind of communalism it wants to ward off.
content: MARSEILLE, France — Once again, terrorism strikes France — and once again, terrorism is exposing the country’s dangerous contradictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Halloween Makeup Ideas, From ‘Euphoria’ to ‘Twilight’
description: Because we could all use a little escapism this year.
content: It should come as no surprise that Halloween will look a bit different this year, but one normal morsel you can count on is that Party City is probably fresh out of cat ears by now. If you’ve left your costume to the last minute, do not fret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: George Shultz Speaks Out for Renewing U.S. Leadership Overseas
description: At a moment when the United States has pulled back from its allies, the former secretary of state lamented the Trump administration’s allergy to international accords.
content: WASHINGTON — In the final years of the Cold War, Secretary of State George P. Shultz negotiated the first arms-control treaty in history to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons, a crowning achievement of President Ronald Reagan’s tenure and the start of a new era of nuclear de-escalation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: England to Shut Pubs, Restaurants and Most Shops as Virus Surges
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s cabinet proposed the move on Saturday as medical experts warned that the virus would soon overwhelm hospitals if the government did not take draconian action.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced plans on Saturday to shut down pubs, restaurants and most retail shops throughout England, a stark reversal in the face of grim projections that the country could face a deadly winter from the coronavirus unless it takes draconian action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Annie Karni
title: Did President Trump Keep His First-Term Promises? Let’s Look at 5 of Them
description: Mr. Trump won the presidency in 2016 after making more than 100 promises. Here’s where some stand four years later and what some of his supporters think of them.
content: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
title: An Ancient Hill and Forgotten Dead: Afghanistan’s Haunted Outpost
description: Its name was Observation Post Rock. The outpost is the backdrop for a ghost story, and is known for strange voices, radio static and the creeping fear of being watched.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — It seemed the perfect vantage point for the Marines: a 30-foot-high dirt pile overlooking the low-lying poppy fields of Helmand Province. What they could not explain were the strange lights at night, the whispers in the darkness, the mysterious radio static, the sudden chill in a summer breeze and the recurring whiff of corpses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Florida’s Republican Heartland, Some Retirees Shift to Vote for Biden
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 31, 2020.
content: “For me, at 71, it’s stealing a lot of the percentage of my remaining life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Todd Heisler
title: Campaign 2020: Let’s Never Do This Again
description: It’s not hope or change. It’s not making anything great. It’s just about making it through.
content: ATLANTA — The masks, when used, can muffle the dueling chants of a live-action partisan clash. But the messages of this election season still have a way of carrying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tochi Onyebuchi
title: Float Like a Butterfly, Sting Like a Bee: A Black Hero’s Boyhood
description: “Becoming Muhammad Ali,” by James Patterson and Kwame Alexander, is a poetic retelling of the legendary boxer’s youth.
content: BECOMING MUHAMMAD ALIWritten by James Patterson and Kwame AlexanderIllustrated by Dawud Anyabwile
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: The Year of Blur
description: How isolation, monotony and chronic stress are destroying our sense of time.
content: For Kate Baer, a poet in Harrisburg, Pa., 2020 feels like a time warp. She compared it to when she and four friends escaped to a woodsy cabin in Maryland and tried cannabis edibles. “Time stopped,” Ms. Baer, 35, said. “And this is how time feels in this pandemic. Fluid and very confusing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Entrada Kelly
title: ‘Square Dancing Belongs Somewhere Far Away … Like the 1800s’
description: In “Lupe Wong Won’t Dance,” a seventh-grade girl who dreams of becoming a major-league pitcher is horrified by a new unit in gym class: square dancing.
content: LUPE WONG WON’T DANCEBy Donna Barba Higuera
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: My Co-op Is Losing Revenue in the Pandemic. Do I Have to Pay?
description: Co-op shareholders are responsible for keeping the building financially stable. But what happens when they don’t want to pay a new fee?
content: Q: I live in a Manhattan co-op. Our building plans to levy an assessment on shareholders because it is no longer receiving rent from commercial tenants due to Covid-19. We’ve already been paying an assessment for two years for other reasons. That fee was supposed to end soon, now it might increase. Do I have a legal right to fight this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez and Hannah Beech
title: Typhoon Goni Leaves Philippines After Only Grazing Manila
description: With sustained winds of up to 135 miles an hour at landfall, the storm barreled across Luzon, the country’s most populous island, but mostly missed the capital. At least 16 people were killed.
content: Typhoon Goni, which made landfall in the Philippines with intense winds early on Sunday morning, by the end of the day appeared to have spared the area in and around the capital Manila, with its 13 million residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Renée Watson
title: ‘Everyone Needs a Buddy’
description: In Varian Johnson and Shannon Wright’s graphic novel “Twins,” sisters navigate a sometimes cruel and changing world.
content: TWINSWritten by Varian JohnsonIllustrated by Shannon Wright
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph E. Stiglitz
title: Republicans, Not Biden, Are About to Raise Your Taxes
description: President Trump built in tax increases beginning in 2021, for nearly everyone but those at the very top.
content: The Trump administration has a dirty little secret: It’s not just planning to increase taxes on most Americans. The increase has already been signed, sealed and delivered, buried in the pages of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Cut Off From the World Again, Australia Now Finds Silver Linings
description: After chafing against their isolation for so long, Australians these days are finding island life a privilege when pestilence lies beyond.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — They used to call it “the tyranny of distance.” Australia’s remoteness was something to escape, and for generations, the country that hates being referred to as “down under” has been rushing toward the world. Trade and immigration made Australians richer than the Swiss, creating a culture where life can be complete only with overseas trips and imported purchases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Lucy Tompkins
title: How Are Americans Catching the Virus? Increasingly, ‘They Have No Idea’
description: New outbreaks used to be traced back to crowded factories and rowdy bars. But now, the virus is so widespread not even health officials are able to keep up.
content: When the coronavirus first erupted in Sioux Falls, S.D., in the spring, Mayor Paul TenHaken arrived at work each morning with a clear mission: Stop the outbreak at the pork plant. Hundreds of employees, chopping meat shoulder to shoulder, had gotten sick in what was then the largest virus cluster in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lev Grossman
title: Philip Pullman’s New ‘Dark Materials’ Book Brims With Familiar Delights
description: “Serpentine” — which features, once again, the unquenchably curious Lyra — juxtaposes light and dark, innocence and experience.
content: SERPENTINEWritten by Philip PullmanIllustrated by Tom Duxbury
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Maggie Haberman
title: Vehicles flying Trump flags try to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas.
description: Vehicles flying Trump flags tried to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas. Trump chuckled about it at a rally later that evening.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Multiple vehicles bearing Trump flags and signs surrounded a Biden-Harris campaign bus heading from San Antonio to Austin on Friday, forcing campaign officials to scrap two campaign events, according to reports by Democratic officials on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Nick Corasaniti and Kathleen Gray
title: Can Trump Woo Enough Black Men to Hurt Biden in Battleground States?
description: On the ground and in TV ads, the candidates are in an intense and surprising battle for Black male voters, who are crucial for Democrats trying to win back Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
content: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Investing for the Future in the United States of Agita
description: No matter who wins the presidency, a lot of people are going to be disappointed. Maybe even scared. But it’s no time to act rashly.
content: Four years ago, I didn’t have a plan. Donald Trump was the surprise winner of the 2016 presidential election, and I wasn’t quite sure what to say to the people who were on the verge of losing their minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daryl Austin
title: Spirits of Grandfathers Past
description: My wife and I thought we were two strangers meeting on social media. Turns out, we shared some history.
content: Grouse Creek, Utah, is about as off the beaten path as a town can be. To access this sleepy community, you have to cross miles of dirt and gravel roads over hilly terrain. A tiny two-pump gas station is the town’s only commercial building, along with a Bureau of Land Management bunkhouse, a shed-like post office, a small schoolhouse and a church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Crispr Gene Editing Can Cause Unwanted Changes in Human Embryos, Study Finds
description: Instead of addressing genetic mutations, the Crispr machinery prompted cells to lose entire chromosomes.
content: A powerful gene-editing tool called Crispr-Cas9, which this month nabbed the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for two female scientists, can cause serious side effects in the cells of human embryos, prompting them to discard large chunks of their genetic material, a new study has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump will barnstorm Pennsylvania as both campaigns focus on the crucial state.
description: President Trump plans four stops in Pennsylvania on Saturday, and the Biden campaign will be there on Sunday and Monday.
content: President Trump will hold four rallies across Pennsylvania on Saturday and his wife, Melania, will host a fifth event in the swing state, as both the president and his Democratic challenger, Joseph R. Biden Jr., zero in on what could be a linchpin in the race for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Camp Uses Online Gimmick to Fuel Donations Into December
description: The Trump campaign is now automatically checking a box to create recurring weekly donations from supporters until mid-December.
content: President Trump’s campaign is raising money for a prolonged political and legal fight long after Nov. 3 and recently began automatically checking a box to withdraw additional weekly contributions from online donors through mid-December — nearly six weeks after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The ‘Wall’ Is Still Motivating Voters. But This Time Is It Against Trump?
description: Immigration was a defining issue for President Trump in 2016. It’s less dominant in 2020, and it is motivating his critics as well as his supporters.
content: YUMA, Ariz. — It might be seen as a monument to the massive changes the Trump administration has brought to the country’s immigration system. Or it could be seen as a reason people are fighting fiercely to vote him out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Fights in Front of Fans Test Boxing’s Business in the Pandemic Era
description: Gervonta Davis and Leo Santa Cruz will fight on pay-per-view and in front of fans at the Alamodome. Two weeks ago, another big fight was not sold separately for viewers, and did not allow paying spectators.
content: Gervonta Davis, a fighter nicknamed Tank, is honored to have a live audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: When Parents Lose Their Jobs, Their Children Also Suffer. But Sometimes There’s a Consolation.
description: The sudden increase of time with their children has reminded some low-income parents of what they have been missing. “It’s an odd silver lining, but it’s there,” says Jane Waldfogel, a professor at the Columbia School of Social Work.
content: In six months without steady work, Gregory Pike, a single father in Las Vegas, has fallen behind on his rent and utilities, borrowed money he cannot repay, turned to food stamps and charity, and fretted that his setbacks may cloud his daughter’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The Election Work Diary of a Reporter With 2.5 Million Subscribers
description: Peter Hamby hosts “Good Luck America” on Snapchat. “My North Star is really the low-information news consumer,” he says. “That’s not an insult.”
content: Peter Hamby has found a way to be a political journalist for a new generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aljean Harmetz
title: Sean Connery, Who Embodied James Bond and More, Dies at 90
description: To legions of fans who have watched a parade of actors play Agent 007, none played the part as magnetically or as indelibly as Mr. Connery.
content: Sean Connery, the irascible Scot from the slums of Edinburgh who found international fame as Hollywood’s original James Bond, dismayed his fans by walking away from the Bond franchise and went on to have a long and fruitful career as a respected actor and an always bankable star, has died in Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How the Skakel-Moxley Murder Case Unfolded Over Four Decades
description: Prosecutors in Connecticut said they did not have enough evidence to pursue a second trial against Michael C. Skakel, who was convicted of killing Martha Moxley in 1975 when they were both 15.
content: Prosecutors in Connecticut said on Friday that they would not retry Michael C. Skakel for the murder of his 15-year-old neighbor 45 years ago, ending a case that transfixed much of the country and went all the way up to the United States Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Take On the Tech Barons
description: Something has to be done about the technology sector. Here’s what to keep in mind.
content: In a rare bit of bipartisanship, Democratic and Republican lawmakers now agree that Big Tech has gotten too big, too powerful, too quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: A Frazzled World Holds Its Breath While the U.S. Chooses Its Leader
description: President Trump turned American foreign policy inside out, to the benefit of some nations and consternation of others. Now both groups are watching attentively to see which direction the U.S. goes next.
content: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Dramatic Rescues After Major Earthquake Kills at Least 39 in Turkey
description: The magnitude-7.0 quake that struck in the Aegean Sea also killed at least two people in Greece. Hundreds were injured in Turkey and many thousands displaced.
content: After a day of dramatic rescues, residents in the Turkish city of Izmir clung to hope Saturday night that survivors might still be found in the devastation of the magnitude-7.0 earthquake that killed at least 39 people in Turkey and Greece, injured more than 800 and leveled numerous residential buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: John Forbes returns with a proper cryptic challenge.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — I’m getting down to the nitty-gritty this week — quick explainers and links to spoilers. By my reckoning, we have solved one John Forbes cryptic in these environs, but Mr. Forbes is a longtime cryptic “setter” and you can find plenty more of his puzzles for future solves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Susanne Craig
title: Biden and Surrogates Hit Trump on Taxes in Closing Argument
description: “Why should you pay more taxes than Donald Trump?” Joseph R. Biden Jr. asked as he took aim at the president’s taxes and tax policy.
content: As former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his surrogates make their closing arguments in battleground states stressed by economic hardship amid the pandemic, they often focus on one number: $750.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: As Tanzania’s President Wins a Second Term, Opposition Calls for Protests
description: After a poll marred by accusations of widespread fraud and irregularities, one opposition leader warned that the nation could become a “one-party system.”
content: CAIRO — After a pivotal poll marred by violence, opposition arrests and accusations of rigging, Tanzania’s electoral commission said late Friday that President John Magufuli had won a second five-year term — a move that led the opposition to call for peaceful protests on Saturday and urge the international community to reject the result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: What Keeps Facebook’s Election Security Chief Up at Night?
description: The social media company’s head of cybersecurity policy on “perception hacks” and what it will take to have an authentic election.
content: Facebook is not the entire internet. But it does reflect and account for some of the greater web’s chaos. With just days to go, hyperpartisan pages on the platform are churning out propaganda to millions of followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: The Race for Miami’s Perennial Tossup Seat Starts Leaning Democratic
description: Florida’s 26th Congressional District seemed like the rare pickup opportunity for Republicans. But the campaign has been complicated by the coronavirus and the presidential election.
content: MIAMI — It felt like 100 degrees on a recent Saturday when Carlos A. Gimenez, the Republican candidate in Florida’s most competitive congressional race, stood on a busy street corner in the Miami suburbs with a gaggle of masked relatives and campaign volunteers, waving signs at the honking cars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 31, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 31, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 31, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Navy Commandos Rescue American Kidnapped in Niger
description: U.S. Special Operations forces conducted a predawn raid in neighboring Nigeria to free the American before he could be sold to terrorists.
content: WASHINGTON — U.S. Special Operations commandos carried out a predawn raid on Saturday to rescue an American citizen who had been kidnapped this week from his home in southern Niger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray and Scott Tobias
title: 15 Sean Connery Movies to Stream
description: Whether as James Bond or Indiana Jones’s father, the Scottish star played the man’s man with an earthy sexiness, as these performances prove.
content: Sean Connery died Saturday at the age of 90. Best known for originating the role of James Bond in movies, the Scottish actor had a career that lasted nearly 60 years, most of which he spent playing a variety of “man’s man” roles — from suave spies to violent brutes. At a time when most popular British thespians were known as Shakespearean-trained aesthetes, Connery became an international star with a screen presence that was earthier and sexier. His musical highland burr and awe-inspiring physicality immediately drew eyes and ears, even when he was playing opposite some of the most accomplished and attractive performers of his generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Typhoon Goni Makes Landfall in Philippines, Packing ‘Catastrophic’ Winds
description: “We are forecasting widespread destruction,” an official said of the typhoon, which made landfall early Sunday.
content: MANILA — Typhoon Goni, expected to be the strongest storm to hit the Philippines this year, made landfall on Sunday morning, with weather officials predicting “catastrophic wind damage” as it roared through the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: One More Thing the Pandemic Election Upended: First Campaign Job Rites of Passage
description: Young staff members are adjusting to a campaign trail altered by the coronavirus, working long hours from their childhood bedrooms.
content: When Alejandra Escobar signed up to work her first campaign job as a field organizer with the Nebraska Democratic Party, she pictured knocking on doors and talking to voters one-on-one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: Americans Surge to Polls: ‘I’m Going to Vote Like My Life Depends on It’
description: Anxious but determined, Americans are pushing through challenges like the pandemic and long lines to cast their ballot. The country is on course to surpass 150 million votes for the first time.
content: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Eggers
title: In Times of Crisis, Life-Affirming Picture Books
description: These new works from Tomi Ungerer, Sophie Blackall and Christian Robinson are realistic and — without being soppy — filled with hope.
content: Tomi Ungerer, who died in 2019, was a wonderfully idiosyncratic, uncompromising artist whose books never condescended to young readers with platitudes or secondhand morality. His books, in fact, rarely seemed intended for kids at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Networks Pledge Caution for an Election Night Like No Other
description: Complicated ballot counts and a president’s baseless claims of vote-rigging are two of the challenges facing TV anchors and executives.
content: Batches of ballots that will be counted at different times, depending on the swing state. Twitter gadflies and foreign agents intent on sowing confusion. A president who has telegraphed for months that he may not accept results he deems unfavorable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Annie Karni
title: Trump Dismisses Virus Coverage and Biden Dismisses Virus Leadership: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: President Trump has complained this week of what he calls a media obsession with the coronavirus pandemic. The message from Democrats has been united — all coronavirus, all the time.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Danielle Ivory and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: ‘A Slow Killer’: Nursing Home Residents Wither in Isolation Forced by the Virus
description: Nursing homes set restrictions to lower risks, but Covid-19 has continued spreading in some homes, and residents are now grappling with consequences from isolation.
content: KIRKLAND, Wash. — After months of near-isolation inside his senior care facility, Charlie no longer recognizes his wife of almost 50 years. In another nursing home, Susan’s toenails grew so long that she could not squeeze into her shoes. Ida lost 37 pounds and stopped speaking. Minnie cried and asked God to just take her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Do Dunkin’ and Arby’s Go Together? Private Equity Group Bets $11 Billion They Do
description: Inspire Brands, backed by Roark Capital, is assembling a portfolio of quick-service restaurant chains it thinks will withstand the pandemic.
content: In one of the largest restaurant deals in more than a decade, Dunkin’ will join some of America’s best-known restaurant chains, including Arby’s and Buffalo Wild Wings, under a single privately held owner.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Comfort Food Forever
description: Hearty and consoling dishes.
content: Ali Slagle’s French onion macaroni and cheese (above) is one of more than 400 warming dishes featured in the super collection here. Make a vegetarian chili or stew, chocolate pancakes covered with raspberries and caramel sauce, or try a new fried chicken recipe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Did This Building Grow a Beard? Nope. Those Are Legs.
description: Daddy longlegs will sometimes collect in large groups. Don’t mistake their dangling limbs for fur.
content: Shortly before Halloween in 2018, an administrative building at Glacier Bay National Park & Preserve in Alaska began to sprout a beard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Kentucky Police Training Quoted Hitler and Urged ‘Ruthless’ Violence
description: A training slide show that urged officers to “always fight to the death” is no longer used but has raised an outcry in a state that has struggled with police violence.
content: A slide show once shown to cadets training to join the Kentucky State Police includes quotations attributed to Adolf Hitler and Robert E. Lee, says troopers should be warriors who “always fight to the death” and encourages each trooper in training to be a “ruthless killer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchir Sharma
title: The Economy Is Down. Why Are Home Prices Up?
description: Government efforts to stimulate growth are lifting markets of all kinds everywhere.
content: Many Americans will have heard stories about people fearful of the pandemic fleeing from crowded cities and driving up home prices in the rest of the country. But there is a much bigger tale to tell here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Stanford Study Seeks to Quantify Infections Stemming From Trump Rallies
description: The researchers used a statistical model to extrapolate infections tied to 18 rallies, and the study’s figures were not based on individual cases traced directly to particular campaign events.
content: [Follow our live Trump vs Biden 2020 election updates and analysis.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Rescue Workers Search for Survivors After Major Earthquake in Turkey
description: A magnitude-7.0 quake that struck in the Aegean Sea also killed at least two people in Greece. Hundreds in Turkey were injured and many thousands displaced.
content: A magnitude-7.0 quake that struck in the Aegean Sea also killed at least two people in Greece. Hundreds in Turkey were injured and many thousands displaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Obama Rips Into Trump During Drive-In Biden Rally
description: Former President Barack Obama on Saturday joined Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, on the campaign trail in Flint, Mich. It was their first joint in-person appearance of 2020.
content: Former President Barack Obama on Saturday joined Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic presidential nominee, on the campaign trail in Flint, Mich. It was their first joint in-person appearance of 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Britain Expands Coronavirus Restrictions
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced expansive new restrictions on Saturday that effectively establish a national lockdown amid an increase in coronavirus cases.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced expansive new restrictions on Saturday that effectively establish a national lockdown amid an increase in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump and the Working Class
description: “Mr. Trump presented himself as a class traitor who would bring the billionaires to heel,” but did the opposite, a reader says.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
